Fungal infection.summary: A skin infection caused by fungi such as dermatophytes or Candida. Common in hot, humid climates. Presents as itchy, red, scaly patches on the skin, groin, feet, or nails.
home_care: Keep the affected area clean and dry at all times
Wear loose, breathable cotton clothing
Avoid sharing towels, clothing, or personal items
Wash clothes and bedsheets in hot water and dry in sunlight
Apply antifungal powder to skin folds after bathing
Avoid scratching the affected area to prevent spreading
warning_signs: Infection spreading to large areas of the body
Pus or fluid oozing from the affected area
Fever developing along with the skin infection
No improvement after 2 weeks of antifungal treatment
Infection on the scalp with hair loss

recommended_medicines.reason: Kills fungal organisms on the skin
Systemic antifungal for widespread or resistant infections
Relieves itching and discomfort

follow_up_questions: Where exactly on your body is the rash or itchy area?
How long have you had this skin problem?
Does anyone else in your family have a similar rash?
Have you tried any creams or ointments already?
Do you work in a place where you sweat a lot?

Allergy.summary: An overreaction of the immune system to substances like dust, pollen, certain foods, or insect stings. Symptoms include sneezing, runny nose, itchy eyes, skin rashes, or swelling.
home_care: Identify and avoid the trigger that causes the allergy
Keep the house clean and dust-free, especially sleeping areas
Use a clean cloth over nose and mouth when sweeping or in dusty areas
Wash bed covers and pillows regularly in hot water
Apply cold compress on skin rashes to reduce itching
Drink warm water with tulsi or ginger for nasal congestion
warning_signs: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
Difficulty breathing or wheezing
Dizziness or feeling faint after exposure to allergen
Rapid heartbeat with skin rash
Severe vomiting or diarrhea after eating a food

recommended_medicines.reason: Blocks histamine to reduce allergic symptoms
Non-sedating antihistamine for persistent allergy symptoms
Soothes itchy skin and provides cooling relief

follow_up_questions: What do you think triggered the allergy (food, dust, medicine, insect bite)?
Do you have any swelling in your face, lips, or throat?
Are you having any difficulty breathing?
Have you had this type of reaction before?
Are you currently taking any medications?

GERD.summary: Gastroesophageal reflux disease occurs when stomach acid frequently flows back into the food pipe. Causes heartburn, chest discomfort, sour taste in the mouth, and difficulty swallowing. Common after heavy or spicy meals.
home_care: Eat smaller, more frequent meals instead of large meals
Avoid spicy, oily, fried, and acidic foods
Do not lie down for at least 2-3 hours after eating
Elevate the head end of the bed by 6 inches using bricks or blocks
Avoid tea, coffee, tobacco, and alcohol
Maintain a healthy weight through moderate exercise
Chew food slowly and thoroughly
warning_signs: Difficulty swallowing food or sensation of food getting stuck
Vomiting blood or dark coffee-ground colored vomit
Black or tarry stools
Unintentional weight loss
Persistent chest pain (must rule out heart attack)

recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces stomach acid production effectively
Proton pump inhibitor that heals damaged food pipe lining
Provides quick relief from heartburn and acidity

follow_up_questions: How often do you experience heartburn or acid coming up?
Do you have any difficulty swallowing food?
Do you smoke, chew tobacco, or drink alcohol?
What type of food do you usually eat (spicy, oily)?
Do your symptoms get worse at night when lying down?

Chronic cholestasis.summary: A condition where bile flow from the liver is reduced or blocked over a long period. Causes yellowing of skin and eyes, intense itching, dark urine, pale stools, and fatigue. Requires medical evaluation to determine the cause.
home_care: Follow a low-fat diet to reduce strain on the liver
Avoid alcohol completely
Keep skin moisturized to reduce itching
Take cool baths with oatmeal or baking soda for itch relief
Eat small, frequent meals rich in fruits and vegetables
Stay well hydrated with clean water
Avoid self-medication, especially paracetamol in high doses
warning_signs: Severe abdominal pain in the upper right side
High fever with chills and yellowing of eyes
Rapid worsening of jaundice
Confusion or altered mental state
Swelling of the abdomen or legs
Bleeding from gums or nose without reason

recommended_medicines.reason: Improves bile flow and protects liver cells

recommended_medicines.frequency: Once or twice daily mixed in water
recommended_medicines.reason: Binds bile acids and reduces severe itching
Provides relief from intense itching at night

follow_up_questions: Have you noticed yellowing of your eyes or skin?
Is your urine darker than usual (tea-colored)?
Are your stools pale or clay-colored?
Do you have severe itching, especially at night?
Do you drink alcohol? If yes, how much and how often?
Have you had any liver problems before?

Drug Reaction.summary: An unwanted reaction caused by a medication. Can range from mild skin rashes to severe life-threatening reactions. May occur with any medicine including traditional or herbal remedies. Important to identify the offending drug.
home_care: Stop the suspected medicine immediately and note its name
Keep a list of all medicines being taken to show the doctor
Apply calamine lotion on skin rashes for relief
Take cool baths to soothe widespread skin irritation
Drink plenty of water to help flush the drug from the body
Do not take the suspected medicine again without doctor advice
warning_signs: Swelling of the face, tongue, or throat
Difficulty breathing or tightness in chest
Blistering or peeling of the skin
High fever with widespread rash
Severe blisters in mouth, eyes, or genital area
Rapid heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting
Yellowing of the eyes (liver damage)

recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces allergic reaction symptoms like rash and itching
Reduces severe inflammation and allergic response (doctor supervision required)
Soothes skin irritation and itching

follow_up_questions: Which medicine did you start taking recently before this reaction?
How long after taking the medicine did the reaction start?
Do you have rash, itching, swelling, or breathing difficulty?
Have you ever had a drug reaction before? To which medicine?
Are you taking any other medicines, including traditional or herbal remedies?

Peptic ulcer disease.summary: Sores that develop on the inner lining of the stomach or upper small intestine. Causes burning stomach pain, bloating, nausea, and sometimes vomiting. Often caused by H. pylori bacteria or prolonged use of painkillers like ibuprofen.
home_care: Eat small, frequent meals at regular times
Avoid spicy, sour, and fried foods
Stop smoking and tobacco use completely
Avoid alcohol as it worsens ulcers
Do not take painkillers like ibuprofen or aspirin without doctor advice
Manage stress through relaxation and regular sleep
Eat more fruits like banana and papaya which soothe the stomach
warning_signs: Vomiting blood (red or dark brown coffee-ground material)
Black, tarry, or bloody stools
Sudden severe abdominal pain that does not go away
Feeling dizzy or fainting
Rapid unintentional weight loss
Unable to eat or keep food down

recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces stomach acid and allows ulcer to heal

recommended_medicines.frequency: Four times daily on empty stomach
recommended_medicines.reason: Forms a protective coating over the ulcer to promote healing
Kills H. pylori bacteria which causes most ulcers

follow_up_questions: Where exactly is the pain in your abdomen?
Does the pain get better or worse after eating?
Have you noticed any blood in your vomit or stools?
Do you take painkillers (ibuprofen, aspirin) regularly?
Do you smoke, chew tobacco, or drink alcohol?

AIDS.summary: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome is caused by HIV virus. It severely weakens the immune system, making the body unable to fight infections. Spreads through unprotected sex, contaminated blood, shared needles, and mother to child. Early treatment with antiretroviral drugs can help people live long, healthy lives.
home_care: Take all prescribed antiretroviral medicines exactly as directed, never miss doses
Eat a nutritious balanced diet with plenty of proteins, vegetables, and fruits
Drink only clean, boiled water to avoid infections
Practice safe sex and always use condoms
Maintain good personal hygiene and handwashing
Get adequate rest and avoid excessive physical stress
Keep all follow-up appointments at the ART center
Avoid contact with people who have active infections like TB
warning_signs: Persistent fever lasting more than 2 weeks
Rapid unexplained weight loss
Persistent diarrhea lasting more than one month
Persistent cough lasting more than 3 weeks (may indicate TB)
White patches in the mouth or throat
Severe recurring skin infections or rashes
Swollen lymph nodes in neck, armpit, or groin
Confusion, memory loss, or neurological problems

recommended_medicines.reason: First-line antiretroviral therapy recommended by NACO India

recommended_medicines.duration: As prescribed based on CD4 count
recommended_medicines.reason: Prevents opportunistic infections in patients with low immunity
Supports nutritional needs and overall immune health

follow_up_questions: Have you been tested for HIV? What was the result?
Are you currently taking any antiretroviral medicines?
Have you had any recent fever, weight loss, or recurring infections?
When was your last visit to the ART center?
Is anyone in your family also receiving treatment?

Diabetes.summary: A chronic condition where blood sugar levels are too high because the body cannot produce enough insulin or use it effectively. Causes increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision, and slow wound healing. Requires lifelong management with diet, exercise, and medication.
home_care: Eat a balanced diet with more vegetables, dal, whole grains (roti, brown rice)
Reduce intake of sugar, sweets, white rice, maida, and sugary drinks
Walk briskly for at least 30 minutes daily
Check blood sugar regularly at the nearest health center
Take medicines at the same time every day without missing doses
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or swelling
Keep feet clean and dry, wear comfortable footwear
Avoid smoking and alcohol
warning_signs: Blood sugar above 300 mg/dL with nausea or vomiting
Excessive thirst with very frequent urination and rapid weight loss
Fruity smell on breath with drowsiness (diabetic ketoacidosis)
Shaking, sweating, confusion, or fainting (low blood sugar)
Non-healing wound or ulcer on the foot
Sudden blurring or loss of vision
Chest pain or shortness of breath
Numbness or tingling in hands and feet getting worse

recommended_medicines.reason: First-line medicine that lowers blood sugar and improves insulin sensitivity
Stimulates the pancreas to produce more insulin

recommended_medicines.dosage: 1 packet in 1 litre of clean water
recommended_medicines.frequency: Sip throughout the day if dehydrated
recommended_medicines.reason: Prevents dehydration from excessive urination

follow_up_questions: Do you know your current blood sugar level?
Are you taking any diabetes medicines currently? Which ones?
How often do you check your blood sugar?
Have you noticed any wounds on your feet that are not healing?
Do you have a family history of diabetes?
What does your daily diet look like?

Gastroenteritis.summary: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, usually caused by viral or bacterial infection from contaminated food or water. Causes watery diarrhea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and sometimes fever. Common during monsoon season. Main danger is dehydration, especially in children and elderly.
home_care: Give ORS solution frequently in small sips to prevent dehydration
Continue breastfeeding for infants; do not stop
Eat light, easily digestible food like khichdi, curd rice, banana, and dal water
Avoid oily, spicy, or heavy foods until recovery
Drink boiled and cooled water only
Wash hands thoroughly with soap before eating and after using toilet
Rest adequately and avoid strenuous work
Monitor urine output - less urine means more dehydration
warning_signs: No urine output for 6-8 hours (sign of severe dehydration)
Blood or mucus in the stool
High fever above 102°F (39°C)
Continuous vomiting, unable to keep any fluids down
Sunken eyes, very dry mouth, no tears when crying (in children)
Excessive drowsiness, irritability, or confusion
Diarrhea lasting more than 3 days without improvement

recommended_medicines.dosage: 1 packet dissolved in 1 litre clean water
recommended_medicines.frequency: After every loose stool, sip frequently
recommended_medicines.reason: Replaces lost water and electrolytes to prevent dehydration

recommended_medicines.dosage: 20 mg tablet (10 mg for children under 6 months)
recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces duration and severity of diarrhea, especially in children
Reduces fever and body aches

follow_up_questions: How many times have you had loose stools today?
Is there any blood or mucus in the stool?
Are you able to drink fluids or do you vomit everything?
When did you last pass urine?
Did you eat outside food or drink untreated water recently?
Is anyone else in your household also having similar symptoms?

Bronchial Asthma.summary: A chronic lung condition where airways become narrow, swollen, and produce extra mucus, making breathing difficult. Causes wheezing, coughing (especially at night), chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Triggered by dust, smoke, cold air, exercise, or allergens.
home_care: Avoid known triggers like dust, smoke, strong smells, and cold air
Keep the house clean and well-ventilated but avoid dust exposure
Do not burn wood, dung, or incense inside the house
Always carry your rescue inhaler with you
Use the inhaler correctly - ask health worker to demonstrate technique
Practice slow deep breathing exercises daily
Cover nose and mouth with a cloth in dusty or cold conditions
Avoid smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke
warning_signs: Severe breathlessness - unable to speak in complete sentences
Lips or fingernails turning blue
Rescue inhaler not providing relief after 2-3 puffs
Breathing becoming faster and more labored
Chest feeling very tight with inability to lie down
Drowsiness or confusion during an attack
Peak flow reading below 50% of personal best

recommended_medicines.frequency: 2 puffs as needed during attack (max 8 puffs/day)
recommended_medicines.reason: Quickly opens up narrowed airways during an asthma attack
Reduces airway inflammation and prevents asthma attacks
Prevents airway inflammation and nighttime asthma symptoms

follow_up_questions: How often do you get breathless or wheeze?
Do you wake up at night due to cough or difficulty breathing?
What triggers your asthma (dust, smoke, cold, exercise)?
Do you use an inhaler? How often do you need your rescue inhaler?
Is there a chulha (cooking stove) with wood or dung inside your house?
Does anyone in your family have asthma or allergies?

Hypertension.summary: Persistently high blood pressure (above 140/90 mmHg). Often has no symptoms and is called the 'silent killer'. Over time damages the heart, brain, kidneys, and eyes. Major risk factor for heart attack and stroke. Very common in India, especially with salty diet and sedentary lifestyle.
home_care: Reduce salt intake - avoid papad, pickle, processed foods, and adding extra salt
Eat more fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Walk briskly for at least 30 minutes daily
Maintain a healthy body weight
Quit smoking and tobacco in all forms
Limit or stop alcohol consumption
Manage stress through yoga, meditation, or deep breathing
Take blood pressure medicines every day without missing even one dose
Get blood pressure checked regularly at the nearest health center
warning_signs: Severe headache with blurred vision
Chest pain or tightness
Sudden numbness or weakness on one side of the body
Difficulty speaking or understanding speech (stroke warning)
Blood in the urine
Severe nosebleed that does not stop
Shortness of breath at rest
Blood pressure reading above 180/120 mmHg

recommended_medicines.reason: Relaxes blood vessels to lower blood pressure
Lowers blood pressure and protects the heart and kidneys
Removes extra salt and water from the body to lower blood pressure

follow_up_questions: Do you know your blood pressure reading?
Are you currently taking any blood pressure medicines?
How much salt do you consume daily? Do you eat pickles, papad?
Do you get regular physical exercise or do you have a sedentary lifestyle?
Do you have diabetes or any heart or kidney problems?
Does anyone in your family have high blood pressure?

Migraine.summary: A neurological condition causing intense, throbbing headaches usually on one side of the head. Often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Attacks can last hours to days. Common triggers include stress, lack of sleep, certain foods, and hormonal changes.
home_care: Rest in a quiet, dark room during an attack
Apply a cold cloth or ice pack wrapped in a towel to the forehead
Drink water as dehydration can worsen headaches
Maintain a regular sleep schedule - sleep and wake at the same time
Eat meals at regular times; do not skip meals
Identify and avoid personal triggers (stress, certain foods, bright lights)
Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing
Keep a headache diary to track triggers and frequency
warning_signs: Worst headache of your life - sudden and severe ('thunderclap')
Headache with high fever and stiff neck
Headache with confusion, seizures, or loss of consciousness
New headache pattern after age 50
Headache with weakness or numbness on one side of the body
Vision loss that does not recover after the headache
Headache getting progressively worse over days to weeks

recommended_medicines.reason: Relieves mild to moderate headache pain
Reduces pain and inflammation during migraine attack
Controls nausea and vomiting associated with migraine

follow_up_questions: Is the headache on one side or both sides of the head?
Do you have nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light during the headache?
How often do you get these headaches?
Do you notice anything that triggers the headaches (stress, foods, sleep)?
Have you had any vision changes or aura before the headache starts?
How long do your headaches usually last?

Cervical spondylosis.summary: Age-related wear and tear of the spinal discs and bones in the neck. Very common after age 40. Causes neck pain, stiffness, headaches, and sometimes numbness or tingling in the arms and hands. Worsened by prolonged bending of the neck (looking at phones) and poor posture.
home_care: Maintain good neck posture - keep the head straight, not bent forward
Avoid prolonged use of mobile phone with neck bent down
Use a thin, firm pillow for sleeping - avoid thick or very soft pillows
Do gentle neck exercises as shown by a physiotherapist
Apply warm compress or hot water bottle to the neck for 15-20 minutes
Avoid carrying heavy loads on the head
Take regular breaks if working at a desk or computer
Avoid sudden jerky movements of the neck
warning_signs: Weakness in arms or legs or difficulty walking
Loss of bladder or bowel control
Numbness or tingling spreading down both arms
Loss of balance or coordination
Severe pain not relieved by any medicine
Dropping things frequently due to hand weakness

recommended_medicines.reason: Relieves neck pain safely
Reduces pain and inflammation in the neck
Relieves muscle spasm and stiffness in the neck

follow_up_questions: Where exactly is the pain - neck, shoulders, or arms?
Do you have any numbness or tingling in your hands or fingers?
Does the pain get worse with any particular movement or posture?
What is your daily work - do you sit at a desk or do physical labor?
How often do you use your mobile phone with your head bent down?
Have you had any weakness in your arms or difficulty gripping things?

Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).summary: Bleeding in the brain that damages brain tissue, causing sudden weakness or paralysis of one side of the body, difficulty speaking, severe headache, and loss of consciousness. This is a medical emergency. Quick treatment within the first few hours can save life and reduce disability.
home_care: CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES IMMEDIATELY - this is a life-threatening emergency
Note the exact time when symptoms started (critical for treatment)
Keep the patient lying on their side (recovery position) to prevent choking
Do not give anything to eat or drink as swallowing may be impaired
Keep the patient calm and reassured while waiting for help
Do not move the patient unnecessarily
After hospital discharge, follow the rehabilitation exercises exactly as prescribed
Prevent bedsores by changing position every 2 hours if bedridden
warning_signs: Sudden severe headache - worst headache of life
Sudden weakness or numbness on one side of face, arm, or leg
Sudden difficulty speaking or understanding speech
Sudden loss of vision in one or both eyes
Sudden loss of balance, dizziness, or inability to walk
Loss of consciousness or seizures
Vomiting with severe headache

recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces brain swelling in emergency (hospital only)

recommended_medicines.duration: Ongoing as prescribed for blood pressure control
recommended_medicines.reason: Controls blood pressure to prevent further bleeding
Prevents seizures which can worsen brain damage

follow_up_questions: When exactly did the symptoms start? (Note the time)
Which side of the body is weak or numb?
Can the person speak and understand what you are saying?
Is the person conscious and alert?
Does the person have high blood pressure or diabetes?
Has the person vomited or had a seizure?

Jaundice.summary: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes caused by buildup of bilirubin. Can be caused by liver infection (hepatitis), gallstones, alcohol, or blood disorders. Dark yellow urine and pale stools are common. Needs investigation to find the cause.
home_care: Rest adequately and avoid physical exertion
Drink plenty of clean, boiled water and fresh fruit juices (sugarcane juice is traditionally recommended)
Eat a light, low-fat diet - khichdi, boiled vegetables, fruits
Avoid oily, fried, and spicy food completely
Completely stop alcohol consumption
Do not take any medicines without doctor's advice, especially paracetamol
Maintain good hygiene - wash hands before eating and after toilet
Boil drinking water and ensure food hygiene
warning_signs: Deepening yellow color of eyes and skin
Severe pain in the upper right abdomen
High fever with chills
Confusion, drowsiness, or altered behavior (liver failure sign)
Swelling of the abdomen (fluid accumulation)
Vomiting blood or passing black stools
Very dark (cola-colored) urine with completely white stools
Bruising or bleeding without injury

recommended_medicines.reason: Supports bile flow and liver function
Supports liver recovery and overall nutrition
Helps remove toxins through the gut and prevents liver complications

follow_up_questions: When did you first notice the yellow color in your eyes or skin?
What color is your urine - dark yellow or brown?
What color are your stools - normal, pale, or clay-colored?
Do you have any pain in your abdomen?
Do you drink alcohol? If yes, how much and how often?
Have you traveled recently or eaten street food or untreated water?

Malaria.summary: A serious mosquito-borne disease caused by Plasmodium parasites. Causes high fever with chills and sweating in a cyclic pattern, severe headache, body aches, and fatigue. Can become life-threatening (cerebral malaria) if not treated promptly. Common in rural India, especially during and after monsoon season.
home_care: Get a malaria test (rapid diagnostic test or blood smear) immediately at the nearest health center
Take the full course of antimalarial medicines as prescribed - do not stop early
Use Paracetamol for fever - sponge the body with lukewarm water
Drink plenty of fluids including ORS, clean water, and fresh juices
Sleep under an insecticide-treated bed net (LLIN)
Prevent mosquito bites using repellents and full-sleeved clothing in the evening
Remove stagnant water around the house where mosquitoes breed
Rest and eat light, nutritious food
warning_signs: Fever above 104°F (40°C) that is not coming down
Severe headache with vomiting and stiff neck
Confusion, drowsiness, or unconsciousness (cerebral malaria)
Dark or red colored urine (blackwater fever)
Rapid breathing or difficulty breathing
Severe weakness or inability to stand or walk
Convulsions or seizures
Yellowing of the eyes
Very low urine output

recommended_medicines.dosage: As per body weight (standard adult: 600mg, then 300mg at 6h, 24h, 48h)
recommended_medicines.frequency: As per national malaria treatment protocol
recommended_medicines.reason: Kills malaria parasites in the blood (for P. vivax malaria)
First-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria as per national guidelines

recommended_medicines.frequency: Every 6 hours as needed for fever
recommended_medicines.reason: Controls high fever and body aches

follow_up_questions: When did the fever start and does it come in cycles with chills and sweating?
Have you had a malaria test done? What was the result?
Do you sleep under a mosquito net?
Is there any stagnant water near your house?

Are you experiencing any vomiting, headache, or confusion?

Chicken pox.summary: A highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus. Causes itchy rash with fluid-filled blisters that start on the face and trunk and spread to the whole body. Accompanied by fever, tiredness, and loss of appetite. More serious in adults, pregnant women, and people with weak immunity.
home_care: Keep the patient isolated from others, especially pregnant women and newborns, until all blisters have crusted over
Trim fingernails short to prevent scratching and skin infection
Apply calamine lotion on the blisters to reduce itching
Give cool (not cold) baths with neem leaves in the water
Wear loose, soft cotton clothing
Drink plenty of fluids and eat soft, easy-to-swallow foods
Do not use aspirin or ibuprofen for fever - use only Paracetamol
Change and wash clothes and bed sheets daily
warning_signs: High fever above 104°F (40°C) lasting more than 4 days
Rash becoming very red, warm, swollen, or tender (bacterial infection)
Pus draining from the blisters
Difficulty breathing or persistent cough
Severe headache with stiff neck and vomiting
Difficulty waking up or unusual drowsiness
Chicken pox in a pregnant woman or newborn baby

recommended_medicines.frequency: Every 6 hours as needed for fever
recommended_medicines.reason: Controls fever safely (do NOT use aspirin or ibuprofen)

recommended_medicines.duration: Until blisters dry and crust over
recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces itching and soothes the skin

recommended_medicines.dosage: 10 mg tablet (5 mg for children 6-12 years)
recommended_medicines.reason: Reduces itching and helps with sleep

follow_up_questions: When did the rash first appear and where on the body?
Has the person been vaccinated against chicken pox?
Is the patient a child, adult, or pregnant woman?
Is anyone else in the household showing similar symptoms?
Are the blisters oozing pus or becoming red and swollen?
Is the patient able to eat and drink?

Dengue.summary: A mosquito-borne viral illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes that bite during daytime. Causes sudden high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, severe joint and muscle pain ('breakbone fever'), rash, and fatigue. Can become life-threatening dengue hemorrhagic fever with bleeding and shock.
home_care: Get a dengue test (NS1 antigen or dengue serology) at the nearest health center
Monitor platelet count daily through blood tests
Drink plenty of fluids - ORS, coconut water, fresh juices, clean water
Use only Paracetamol for fever - DO NOT use Aspirin, Ibuprofen, or Diclofenac as they increase bleeding risk
Do lukewarm water sponging for high fever
Eat nutritious soft food - papaya leaf juice is traditionally used
Complete bed rest is essential
Use mosquito nets and repellents to prevent spread to others
Prevent Aedes mosquito breeding - empty all water containers around the house
warning_signs: Severe abdominal pain or persistent vomiting
Bleeding from gums, nose, or blood in vomit or stools
Red spots or patches on the skin (petechiae)
Rapid drop in platelet count below 50,000
Feeling restless then suddenly becoming drowsy or lethargic
Cold, clammy skin with rapid weak pulse (dengue shock)
Difficulty breathing or fluid accumulation
Blood in urine

recommended_medicines.reason: Only safe medicine for fever in dengue (DO NOT use ibuprofen/aspirin)
Prevents dehydration which is the main cause of dengue complications
Controls nausea and vomiting so patient can maintain fluid intake

follow_up_questions: When did the fever start? Is it continuous or does it come and go?
Do you have severe pain behind your eyes or in joints and muscles?
Have you noticed any bleeding from nose, gums, or red spots on skin?
Have you had a dengue test or platelet count done?
Are you able to drink fluids and keep them down?
Has anyone else in your area been diagnosed with dengue recently?

Typhoid.summary: A bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, spread through contaminated water and food. Causes sustained high fever that increases stepwise over days, headache, weakness, stomach pain, and sometimes a rash. Without treatment, can cause intestinal bleeding or perforation. Common in areas with poor sanitation.
home_care: Take the full course of antibiotics as prescribed - do not stop early even if feeling better
Drink only boiled or filtered water
Eat soft, easily digestible food - khichdi, dal, boiled vegetables, curd
Avoid raw vegetables, salads, and street food until fully recovered
Rest completely - avoid physical exertion
Wash hands thoroughly with soap before eating and after using toilet
Monitor temperature twice daily and keep a record
Family members should get tested if they develop fever
warning_signs: Severe abdominal pain or swelling
Blood in the stool or black tarry stools (intestinal bleeding)
Fever not responding to antibiotics after 5 days
Confusion or altered mental state
Persistent vomiting unable to keep medicines down
Rapid heartbeat with cold, clammy skin
Severe weakness or inability to get up from bed

recommended_medicines.reason: Effective antibiotic against typhoid bacteria
Alternative antibiotic for typhoid treatment
Controls the high fever safely

follow_up_questions: How many days have you had fever? Is it increasing gradually?
Have you had a Widal test or blood culture done?
What is your source of drinking water? Do you boil it?
Do you have any abdominal pain or diarrhea?
Have you started any antibiotics? If yes, are you feeling better?
Has anyone else in your family or neighborhood had typhoid recently?

hepatitis A.summary: A viral liver infection spread through contaminated water and food. Causes yellowing of eyes and skin, dark urine, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Usually self-limiting and does not become chronic. Common in areas with poor water and sanitation. Prevented by the Hepatitis A vaccine.
home_care: Complete bed rest is essential during the acute phase
Drink plenty of clean boiled water, ORS, coconut water, and fresh fruit juices
Eat a high-carbohydrate, low-fat diet - rice, khichdi, fruits, boiled vegetables
Avoid oily, fried, and spicy foods completely
Stop alcohol consumption completely
Do not take any medicines without asking the doctor, especially paracetamol
Maintain strict personal hygiene - wash hands before eating and after toilet
Use a separate toilet or clean it after use to prevent spread
warning_signs: Severe vomiting preventing eating or drinking
Increasing drowsiness or confusion (liver failure)
Worsening jaundice (deeper yellow color)
Swelling of the abdomen
Bleeding from gums or nose without reason
Fever returning after initially improving
Very low urine output

recommended_medicines.duration: Until appetite and fluid intake improve
recommended_medicines.reason: Prevents dehydration from vomiting and poor appetite
Controls nausea and vomiting to maintain nutrition
Supports liver recovery and overall nutrition

follow_up_questions: When did the yellowing of your eyes first appear?
What is the color of your urine and stools?
Are you able to eat and drink, or do you vomit everything?
What is your source of drinking water?
Have others in your family or village had similar symptoms?

Hepatitis B.summary: A viral liver infection spread through blood, unprotected sex, shared needles, and mother to child during birth. Can become chronic and lead to liver cirrhosis and liver cancer over years. Many people have no symptoms initially. Preventable by vaccination. Treatable with antiviral medicines.

Hepatitis C.summary: A viral liver infection primarily spread through contaminated blood (unsafe injections, blood transfusions, shared needles). Hepatitis D.summary: A liver infection caused by the Hepatitis D virus, which only occurs in people already infected with Hepatitis B. Makes Hepatitis B disease more severe and rapidly progressive. Spread through contaminated blood and body fluids. Can cause faster progression to liver cirrhosis compared to Hepatitis B alone.

Avoid alcohol completely
Follow a healthy, low-fat diet rich in vegetables and fruits
Do not share razors, toothbrushes, or needles

Get regular blood tests to monitor liver function and viral levels

Hepatitis E.summary: A viral liver infection spread through contaminated water, especially during monsoon and floods. Very common in India. Causes jaundice, nausea, vomiting, fever, and fatigue. Usually self-limiting in most people but can be very dangerous for pregnant women, causing liver failure and high mortality. Outbreaks occur in areas with poor sanitation.
home_care: Complete bed rest during the acute illness
Drink plenty of boiled water, ORS, coconut water, and sugarcane juice
Eat light, low-fat food - khichdi, rice, dal, boiled vegetables, fruits
Avoid oily, fried, spicy food and all non-vegetarian food during illness
Stop alcohol completely
Do not take any medicines without doctor's advice
Boil drinking water and maintain strict food hygiene
Pregnant women with Hepatitis E MUST be hospitalized immediately
warning_signs: Pregnant woman with jaundice (medical emergency)
Worsening jaundice despite rest
Confusion, excessive drowsiness, or irritability
Severe vomiting preventing fluid and food intake
Bleeding from any site
Swelling of abdomen
Very dark urine with minimal output
Fever returning after initially going down

Controls nausea and vomiting to maintain nutrition
Supports liver recovery and overall health

Alcoholic hepatitis.summary: Inflammation and damage of the liver caused by excessive alcohol consumption over time. Causes jaundice, abdominal pain and swelling, fever, nausea, and weakness. Can range from mild to life-threatening liver failure. Complete and permanent alcohol cessation is the most important treatment.
home_care: Stop drinking alcohol completely and permanently - this is the single most important step
Eat a nutritious, high-protein diet to support liver recovery
Take vitamin supplements as prescribed by the doctor
Avoid all self-medication, especially paracetamol
Rest adequately and avoid physical strain
Seek support from family and de-addiction programs to maintain sobriety

Tuberculosis.summary: A serious bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs. Spreads through air when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Causes persistent cough for more than 2-3 weeks, blood in sputum, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue. Fully curable with complete treatment under DOTS program.

Cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing

Common Cold.summary: A mild viral infection of the nose and throat. Causes runny or blocked nose, sneezing, sore throat, mild cough, and sometimes low-grade fever. Usually resolves on its own within 5-7 days. Very common and usually not dangerous. Spread by droplets when an infected person sneezes or coughs.

Drink plenty of warm fluids - warm water, kadha, ginger-tulsi tea, warm soup
Do steam inhalation 2-3 times daily for nasal congestion

Get adequate sleep and rest

Pneumonia.summary: A serious infection of the lungs that fills the air sacs with pus and fluid. Causes high fever, cough with yellowish or bloody sputum, difficulty breathing, chest pain when breathing, and severe weakness. Can be life-threatening, especially in children under 5, elderly, and people with weak immunity. Requires antibiotic treatment.
home_care: Seek medical treatment immediately - pneumonia requires antibiotics
Take the full course of antibiotics as prescribed - do not stop early
Drink plenty of warm fluids to stay hydrated and loosen mucus
Rest completely - avoid all physical exertion
Do steam inhalation to ease breathing
Keep the room well-ventilated but warm
Eat nutritious, easy-to-swallow foods for energy

Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).summary: Swollen blood vessels in and around the anus and lower rectum that can be internal or external (dimorphic means both types present). Causes pain during and after passing stools, bleeding (bright red blood), itching, and sometimes a lump near the anus. Common due to constipation, straining, prolonged sitting, and low-fiber diet.
home_care: Eat a high-fiber diet - whole grains, fruits, vegetables, green leafy vegetables
Drink at least 8-10 glasses of water daily to soften stools
Do not strain during bowel movements - do not sit on the toilet for long

Heart attack.summary: A life-threatening emergency where blood supply to part of the heart muscle is suddenly blocked, usually by a blood clot. Causes crushing chest pain or pressure, pain spreading to left arm, jaw, or back, sweating, breathlessness, and nausea. Every minute of delay in treatment increases heart damage. Immediate action saves lives.
home_care: CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES (108/102) IMMEDIATELY
Make the person sit or lie in a comfortable position (usually propped up)
Loosen tight clothing around the chest and neck
Give an Aspirin (325 mg or chew 4 low-dose tablets) if available and patient is not allergic
Give a Sorbitrate/Nitroglycerin tablet under the tongue if the person has one
Do not give water if the person is not fully conscious
Be prepared to start CPR if the person becomes unconscious and stops breathing
Note the time when symptoms started - tell the doctors
Do not let the person walk or exert themselves - carry them to the vehicle

Hypothyroidism.summary: A condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones, slowing down the body's metabolism. Hyperthyroidism.summary: A condition where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone, speeding up the body's metabolism. Hypoglycemia.summary: Abnormally low blood sugar level (below 70 mg/dL). Most common in people with diabetes taking insulin or certain diabetes medicines. Urinary tract infection.summary: An infection in any part of the urinary system - most commonly the bladder and urethra. Very common in women. Causes burning or pain during urination, frequent urge to urinate, cloudy or foul-smelling urine, and lower abdominal pain. Can spread to kidneys if untreated, causing fever and back pain.
home_care: Drink plenty of water - at least 8-10 glasses daily to flush out bacteria
Do not hold urine - go to the toilet whenever you feel the urge
Urinate before and after sexual intercourse
Wipe from front to back after using the toilet (important for women)
Wear loose cotton undergarments
Maintain good genital hygiene - wash with clean water daily
Avoid using harsh soaps or douches in the genital area
Take the full course of antibiotics even if symptoms improve
warning_signs: High fever with chills and back pain (kidney infection)
Blood in the urine
Nausea, vomiting, or inability to eat
Severe lower abdominal pain
Symptoms not improving after 2-3 days of antibiotics
UTI in a pregnant woman (needs urgent treatment)
UTI in men or children (needs investigation)
Recurring UTIs (3 or more in a year)

recommended_medicines.reason: First-line antibiotic effective against common UTI bacteria
Alternative antibiotic for urinary tract infections
Relieves pain, discomfort, and fever

Psoriasis.summary: A chronic autoimmune skin condition where skin cells grow too quickly, forming thick, red, scaly patches covered with silvery-white scales. Commonly affects elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. Not contagious. Tends to come and go in flare-ups. Can also affect nails and joints. Triggered by stress, infections, and certain medicines.
home_care: Keep the skin well moisturized - apply coconut oil or emollient cream after bathing
Take regular baths with lukewarm water (not hot) to soften scales
Gently remove scales after soaking - do not scratch or pick
Get brief, controlled sun exposure (10-15 minutes) which can help some people
Avoid stress as it triggers flare-ups - practice yoga and meditation
Avoid alcohol and smoking as they worsen psoriasis
Wear soft cotton clothing to reduce skin irritation
Identify and avoid personal triggers (stress, infections, certain medicines)
warning_signs: Psoriasis covering large areas of the body (more than 10%)
Pus-filled blisters on the psoriasis patches
Joint pain and swelling (psoriatic arthritis)
Fever with widespread redness of the skin
Nail changes - pitting, crumbling, or separation from nail bed
Severe itching or pain affecting sleep and daily activities
Depression or severe emotional distress due to the condition

recommended_medicines.frequency: Apply once daily on affected patches (not on face)
recommended_medicines.reason: Strong steroid cream that reduces inflammation and scaling quickly

recommended_medicines.frequency: Apply once daily or use shampoo 2-3 times weekly
recommended_medicines.reason: Slows skin cell growth and reduces scaling, itching, and inflammation

recommended_medicines.frequency: Apply 2-3 times daily, especially after bathing
recommended_medicines.reason: Keeps skin moisturized and reduces dryness, scaling, and itching

Impetigo.summary: A highly contagious bacterial skin infection common in children, caused by Staphylococcus or Streptococcus bacteria. Causes red sores that burst and form honey-colored crusts, usually around the nose, mouth, hands, and forearms. Spreads by direct contact or sharing towels. Common in hot, humid conditions with poor hygiene.
home_care: Gently wash the sores with soap and clean water, then pat dry
Remove crusts gently after soaking with warm water compress
Apply antibiotic ointment as prescribed after cleaning
Cover the sores with a light bandage to prevent spreading
Keep the child's fingernails short to prevent scratching and spreading
Wash hands frequently with soap - both patient and caregivers
Do not share towels, clothing, or bedding with the affected person
Wash the patient's clothing and towels separately in hot water
Keep the child home from school until 24 hours after starting antibiotics
warning_signs: Sores spreading rapidly despite treatment
Fever developing with the skin infection
Red, warm, swollen skin around the sores (cellulitis)
Blisters becoming large and filled with pus
Dark-colored urine after the infection (may indicate kidney problem)
Sores not healing after 3 days of antibiotic treatment
Swollen lymph nodes near the affected area

recommended_medicines.frequency: Apply three times daily on sores after cleaning
recommended_medicines.reason: Topical antibiotic that kills bacteria causing the skin infection
Oral antibiotic for widespread impetigo or when topical treatment is insufficient

recommended_medicines.frequency: Use to clean sores twice daily before applying ointment
recommended_medicines.reason: Antiseptic wash that kills bacteria on the skin surface
